bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.p: This memorandum gives the itinerary of the Japanese steamers running between Asia and Peruvian ports.

div1.head: Memorandum concerning Japanese shipping, May 23, 1923
div1.opener:
CALLAO-PERÚ
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
23 MAY 1923
div1.p:
JAPANESE STEAMERS RUNNING BETWEEN ASIA AND PERUVIAN PORTS.
Ginyo Maru, 6118 T.R..- Rakuyo Maru, 5680 T.R.- Seiyo Maru, 4770
T.R.- Anyo Maru, 5738 T.R.

All these vessels spend two months in the voyage
from Hong Kong to Callao. Her cargo from there, is rice and general
cargo. The return cargo is saltpetre from Chilean ports and little
mineral and wool bales or general.

The itinerary coming to Peru, is as follows:- Hong kong, Moji,
Kobe, Yokohama, Honolulu, Hilo, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Manzanillo,
Blaboa and Callao.- Some times they make an slight difference
touching at Manila or San Pedro, Cal.

When those vessels going back from here to Asia, they make
more or less the same itinerary. All them bring receive coming and going cargo and inmi-
grants, spending six months in a round voyage each one.
div1.closer:
asholulen
A A Surgeon
U S. PHS.
